Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2015 Midwest Conference on Representation Theory will be held November 13-15, 2015, on the campus of University of Missouri, Columbia, Missouri. The conference will gather established experts, recent Ph.D.s, and graduate students for the purpose of discussing and disseminating new research results in the general area of representation theory, a fundamental mathematical subject with applications to many other areas within mathematics. This is the 41st annual meeting of this conference, which serves as an important forum in the field. This award supports participation by graduate students, early career faculty, and senior researchers with no other source of travel funds. The conference website is http://faculty.missouri.edu/~takedas/Midwest_Rep_2015/index.html.

This year's conference will focus of representations of groups over non-archimedean local fields. The representation theory of groups over non-archimedean local fields is closely tied to number theory, in particular to the study of automorphic forms, which are central objects of study in modern number theory. The conference will feature nine speakers, including talks by young researchers on a broad range of topics in the theory of representations of groups over non-archimedean local fields and talks by senior researchers on supercuspidal representations of these groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015  Midwest Representation Theory Conference was held at University of Missouri November 13­15, 2015. The conference was organized by S. DeBacker (Michigan), D. Goldberg (Purdue), D. Jiang (Minnesota), M. Krishnamurthy (Iowa), L. Spice (TCU), and S. Takeda (Missouri). There were 10 speakers over the course of three days: J. Adler (American U.), Moshe Adrian (Queens College), C Chan (Michigan), J. Fintzen (Harvard), F. Gao (Purdue), S. Gindinkin (Rutgers), A. Minguez (Jussieu), B. Romano (Boston College), G. Savin (Utah), and A. Wood (Missouri). These lectures addressed a broad range of topics in representation theory and included applications to other areas of research, including number theory, algebraic geometry, and harmonic analysis. In keeping with the tradition of the Midwest Conference, many of these speakers are early career researchers, including three graduate students close to finishing their doctorates (Chan, Fintzen, Romano), two were on postdoctoral appointments (Gao, Wood), and one was a tenure track assistant professor (Adrian). 

 

Since all the available funds were not expended for this conference, the remaining funds, $10,676.05, was used to support participants for the 2016 Midwest Representation Theory Conference, October 14-16, in Iowa City, Iowa, and additional funding for the 2016 conference was provided by DMS1643125, qith M. Krishnamurthy as PI.  The final report for DMS1643125 has already been filed, and we'll detail the fiscal contribution of the award being reported on here to that conference.
